item.title: The 20 best things Trump did in 2025
item.description: The accomplishments of a stunning year can’t be captured in just 10 items.

item.title: U.S. sanctions are losing their bite
item.description: The Trump administration’s seizure of Venezuela’s tankers are a tacit admission.

item.title: I’m a doctor. I shouldn’t receive better health care than patients.
item.description: Transparency in prices for medical treatment should be offered to everyone.

item.title: Resolution needed
item.description: Michael Ramirez cartoon on government spending and New Year’s resolutions.

item.title: California will miss billionaires when they’re gone
item.description: Larry Page and Peter Thiel adjusted residencies before yearend in case a wealth tax passes.

item.title: Trump and the United Nations come to a head
item.description: The administration is trying to forge a new model for humanitarian aid.

item.title: Cannabis is legitimate. It’s high time the United States follows suit.
item.description: Readers respond to Post articles and commentary.

item.title: Food stamps should help the hungry. And only the hungry.
item.description: Amid Minnesota fraud scandal, Democratic governors are refusing to share SNAP details with the feds.

item.title: Why an aggressive executive is preferable to an aggressive legislature
item.description: Readers respond to Post articles and commentary.

item.title: South Carolina serves up another taste of RFK Jr.’s America
item.description: Yet another measles outbreak shows the consequences of anti-vaccine sentiments.

item.title: What VIPs are proving about quitting
item.description: From Warren Buffett and Clayton Kershaw to Nancy Pelosi, who made an admirable exit in 2025?

item.title: America’s real source of patriotism has been clear for 250 years
item.description: Critiquing the nation on where and how it has fallen short, but from a place of respect and affection.

item.title: Progressives, don’t force 20th-century rules on 21st-century workers
item.description: Gig work is facing death by a thousand regulatory cuts.
